item.title: PUBG And Fortnite Failed Approval in China
item.description: PUBG And Fortnite, alongside various other games have failed to be approved in China. Images are circulating that list several high profile games that the Chinese Online Ethics Review Committee have reviewed and determined to have ethical infractions, alongside the suggested “Recommended Actions”. 20 games have been reviewed, with 9 of them failing to be approved: Stream ‘n Share has reached out to both Epic Games and Blizzard for comment.

item.title: Bethesda Data Breach Reveals Customer Information (Updated)
item.description: After a trialling week, Bethesda has once again found themselves in hot water. Their support page for Fallout 76 Power Armor Edition users was found to be publicly leaking sensitive user information, including receipts which could contain emails, home addresses and even the card used to purchase the game. So far, Bethesda has yet to respond on any public channels, only through a forum reply saying “Hi guys, we’ve resolved this issue.

item.title: Ubisoft Reverts Rainbow Six Siege Changes
item.description: Ubisoft has decided to revert the controversial changes recently made to Rainbow Six Siege which affected several visual in-game elements. In a recent update, Ubisoft stated that: “On November 2nd, we shared an article detailing the Aesthetic Changes coming with Operation Wind Bastion. Since then, our community and players have raised concerns. We have spent the last week working on solutions and have decided that we will be reverting all aesthetic changes.

item.title: YouTuber Shirrako Suspended Over Red Dead Redemption Video (updated)
item.description: YouTube Shirrako has found himself suspended from YouTube after one of his videos entitled “Red Dead Redemption 2 - Beating Up Annoying Feminist” which featured his character punching the NPC in the face went viral with over 1.5 million views, causing several major outlets to report on the video and criticise the game and the YouTube comment section. After reviewing Shirrakos account, YouTube determined that the video featured “gratuitious violence”, which is not acceptable on their site.

item.title: Fallout 76 Beta Missing Client Side Authentication Making Cheating Easy
item.description: Fallout 76 has already become the target of hackers, despite only recenting enter beta. wallhax.com shows off a rather feature rich tool including a 2D radar, field of view correction, stick to target fuction as well as other features, which they claim will be “available at launch”. Reddit user teetharejustdone detailed how the game fails to verify the intergity of game files, leading to the ability to mod the game and potentially use the engines features to exploit game mechanics.

item.title: Australian Senate Bill to Stop Bans on Gaming
item.description: Australian senator David Leyonhjelm has introduced the Freedom of Speech Legislation Amendment proposal, which would amend the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 to: Remove the ban on publications, films and computer games that offend against standards of morality, decency and propriety. And also amend the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to: Remove bans on broadcasting, datacasting and online content, with a specific focus on bans affecting services provided behind paywalls; narrow the guidance provided by government to broadcasting industries and datacasting licensees in the development of codes of practice; remove certain restrictions on subscription television broadcasters and online content services relating to programs or content that has been or would be classified as X 18+, ‘category 1 restricted’ or ‘category 2 restricted’; and remove a ban on broadcasting electoral advertising relating to a federal, state, territory or local election on election day or on the preceding Thursday or Friday.

item.title: Germany Bans Pre Orders Without Set Release Dates
item.description: The Higher Regional Court of Munich has ruled that pre-orders with “vague” release dates are illegal. The issue was brought to the regional court by a German rights advocacy group, who sued Mediamarkt for illegal information in the online ordering of a smartphone. According to the judgement, indeterminate statements regarding the delivery of online goods and orders violates the legal duty of information of the seller. The customer is entitled to a specific delivery date before clicking on the order button, and information such as “soon to be available” are in violation of the consumers rights.

item.title: We Happy Few Denied Classification in Australia
item.description: We Happy Few, first revealed at PAX East 2015, has been denied classification in Australia. According to the Department of Communications and the Arts, We Happy Few was denied classification because: The computer game is classified RC in accordance with the National Classification Code, Computer Games Table, 1. (a) as computer games that “depict, express or otherwise deal with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in such a way that they offend against the standards of morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by reasonable adults to the extent that they should not be classified.

item.title: HuniePop vs the National Center on Sexual Exploitation
item.description: HuniePop has found itself under the pressure of The National Center on Sexual Exploitation (also know as Morality in Media, Inc), self-described as “The leading national organization exposing the links between all forms of sexual exploitation such as child sexual abuse, prostitution, sex trafficking and the public health crisis of pornography”. The group originated in 1962 and was founded by Father Morton A. Hill, Rabbi Julius Neumann and Rev. Robert Wiltenburg as a neighbourhood organisational effort to combat pornography distribution in their local area under the codename “Operation Yorkville”.
